title: Similarity invariance
summary: In linear algebra, similarity invariance is a property exhibited by a function whose value is unchanged under similarities of its domain.  That is, f {\displaystyle f} is invariant under similarities if f ( A ) = f ( B − 1 A B ) {\displaystyle f(A)=f(B^{-1}AB)} where B − 1 A B {\displaystyle B^{-1}AB} is a matrix similar to A.  Examples of such functions include the trace, determinant, characteristic polynomial, and the minimal polynomial.
